> "The potential output of all goods and services that are produced within an economy over a period of time."

# Aggregate Demand
- In microeconomics, the focus of a demand curve is on an individual product in its relationship with its own price.
- When we consider demand within a macroeconomic context, we refer to it as aggregate demand.
- Aggregate is a 'combination of elements' and so when we refer to AD we are referring to "the total demand for goods and services produced in an economy at a given price level." 
- ***AD is GDP***
- ### AD = C + I + G + (X - M)
	-  C (Consumption \[spending by households\])
		- This covers household spending on goods and services by consumers.
		- 60-65% of AD
	-  I (Investments \[spending by businesses\]) 
		- This covers investment spending on fixed capital by firms (e.g. factory)
	- G (government spending)
		- This involves the spending by the government on goods and services (e.g. NHS)
	- (X (exports) & M (imports))
		- Known as net trade. All income earned from selling exports minus all income spent on imports.
